Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is running around in a supermarket, and the parent needs to correct the behavior
Expectation2: Provide initial medical care to patients
Situation2: The ambulance driver is conducting a routine check of the first-aid kit to ensure all supplies are present and not expired.
Story: I was kneeling on the floor of the supermarket, double-checking the contents of my ambulance’s first-aid kit for the third time that week. Gauze, bandages, epinephrine—everything had to be perfect. My mind was on the checklist, but my ears caught the sound of sneakers squeaking and laughter echoing down the aisle. I looked up to see my son darting between displays, weaving dangerously close to a pyramid of canned soup. Other shoppers glanced over, some with disapproval, some with concern. As a parent, I knew I should stop him, teach him about respect and discipline, remind him that running indoors isn’t safe or polite. But as an ambulance driver, I couldn’t afford to lose focus; a missing or expired item could mean the difference between life and death for a patient. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations—my duty to my child, my duty to my patients. I felt the pressure mounting, torn between calling out to my son and finishing my critical check.
